Q35A.question: How likely is it that you could get the following information: if you contacted the local school to find out what the school’s budget is and how the funds have been used?

Q35B.description: Access to information: local government development plan and budget
Q35B.question: How likely is it that you could get the following information: if you contacted your local government office to find out about the local development plan and budget?

Q35C.description: Access to information: local government contracts
Q35C.question: How likely is it that you could get the following information: if you contacted your local government office to request to see a contract for a government-funded project or purchase?

Q36A.question: Imagine you went to a local leader or a local government office to request assistance for a development project in your community, like an improved water supply or community clean-up activity. How likely is it that you could get someone to take action?

Q36B.description: Likelihood of response: reporting teacher misconduct
Q36B.question: If you went to the local school to report teacher misbehavior such as absenteeism or mistreatment of students, how likely is it that you could get someone to take action?

Q36C.question: Imagine you went to a local government office or anti-corruption authority to report corrupt behavior like misuse of funds or requests for bribes. How likely is it that you could get someone to take action?

Q40A.question: In the past 12 months, have you had any contact with a public school?

Q40B.question: How easy or difficult was it to obtain the services you needed from teachers or school officials?

Q40C.question: How often, if ever, did you have to pay a bribe, give a gift, or do a favor for a teacher or school official to get the services you needed?

Q40D.question: When dealing with teachers and school officials, how much do you feel they treated you with respect?

Q41A.description: Contact with public clinics or hospitals
Q41A.question: In the past 12 months, have you had any contact with a public clinic or hospital?

Q41B.question: How easy or difficult was it to obtain the medical care or services you needed?

Q41C.question: How often, if ever, did you have to pay a bribe, give a gift, or do a favor for a health worker or clinic/hospital staff to get the medical care or services you needed?

Q41D.question: When dealing with health workers and clinic or hospital staff, how much do you feel they treated you with respect?

Q41E.description: Problems with public clinics: lack of medicines or supplies
Q41E.question: In the past 12 months, have you encountered any problems in a public clinic or hospital due to a lack of medicines or other supplies?

Q41F.description: Problems with public clinics: absence of medical personnel
Q41F.question: In the past 12 months, have you encountered any problems in a public clinic or hospital due to the absence of doctors or other medical personnel?

Q41G.description: Problems with public clinics: long waiting times
Q41G.question: In the past 12 months, have you encountered any problems in a public clinic or hospital due to long waiting times?

Q41H.description: Problems with public clinics: poor condition of facilities
Q41H.question: In the past 12 months, have you encountered any problems in a public clinic or hospital due to poor facility conditions?

Q42A.description: Attempt to obtain an identity document
Q42A.question: In the past 12 months, have you tried to get an identity document such as a birth certificate, driver's license, passport, voter’s card, or permit from the government?

Q42B.question: How easy or difficult was it to obtain the document you needed?

Q42C.description: Bribery to obtain an identity document
Q42C.question: How often, if ever, did you have to pay a bribe, give a gift, or do a favor for a government official to get the document you needed?

Q42D.description: Respect received from government officials when obtaining documents
Q42D.question: When dealing with government officials to obtain documents, how much do you feel they treated you with respect?

Q43A.question: In the past 12 months, have you requested assistance from the police?

Q43B.question: How easy or difficult was it to obtain the assistance you needed from the police?

Q43C.question: How often, if ever, did you have to pay a bribe, give a gift, or do a favor for a police officer to get the assistance you needed?

Q43D.question: In the past 12 months, how often have you encountered the police in situations such as checkpoints, identity checks, traffic stops, or investigations?

Q43E.description: Bribery to avoid problems with the police
Q43E.question: How often, if ever, did you have to pay a bribe, give a gift, or do a favor for a police officer to avoid a problem during one of these encounters?

Q44A.description: Police professionalism and respect for citizens' rights
Q44A.question: In your opinion, how often do the police operate in a professional manner and respect the rights of all citizens?

Q44B.question: In your opinion, how often do the police stop drivers without good reason?

Q44C.question: In your opinion, how often do the police use excessive force in managing protests or demonstrations?

Q44D.question: In your opinion, how often do the police use excessive force when dealing with criminals?

Q44E.question: In your opinion, how often do the police engage in criminal activities?

Q66A.question: Over the past 10 years, has the severity of droughts in your area increased or decreased?

Q66B.question: Over the past 10 years, has the severity of flooding in your area increased or decreased?

Q67A.question: Have you heard about climate change?

Q67B.question: Do you think climate change is making life in this country better or worse?

Q68A.description: Belief in citizens' role in limiting climate change
Q68A.question: Can ordinary citizens play a role in limiting climate change?

Q68B.description: Belief in government action against climate change
Q68B.question: Should the government take steps now to limit climate change, even if it is expensive or causes job losses?

Q69.description: Who is primarily responsible for limiting climate change
Q69.question: Who should have primary responsibility for limiting climate change and reducing its impact?

values.0: No one/Climate change can't be stopped

Q70A.description: Do more to fight climate change: citizens
Q70A.question: Are ordinary citizens doing enough to limit climate change, or should they do more?

values.3: Need to do a lot more

Q70B.description: Do more to fight climate change: business and industry
Q70B.question: Is business and industry doing enough to limit climate change, or should they do more?

values.3: Need to do a lot more

Q70C.description: Do more to fight climate change: government
Q70C.question: Is the government doing enough to limit climate change, or should they do more?

values.3: Need to do a lot more

Q70D.description: Do more to fight climate change: developed countries
Q70D.question: Are developed countries doing enough to limit climate change, or should they do more?

values.3: Need to do a lot more

Q71.question: Which statement do you agree with more? (1) The government should focus on creating jobs and increasing incomes, even if that means increasing pollution. (2) The government should focus on preventing pollution and protecting the environment, even if it causes job losses or disruptions.

Q72A.question: How serious of a problem is pollution, such as trash accumulation or damage to air and water quality, in your community?

Q72B.description: Most important environmental issue in community
Q72B.question: What is the most important environmental issue in your community?

Q72C.description: Plastic bags as a source of pollution
Q72C.question: Do you agree or disagree that plastic bags are a major source of pollution?

Q72D.description: Who is responsible for reducing pollution
Q72D.question: Who should be primarily responsible for reducing pollution and keeping your community clean?

Q72E.question: Should the government do more or less to limit pollution and protect the environment?

Q73A.description: Government regulation of natural resource extraction
Q73A.question: Should the government impose stricter regulations on natural resource extraction to reduce environmental damage?

Q73B.description: Public voice in natural resource extraction decisions
Q73B.question: Do ordinary citizens have a voice in decisions about natural resource extraction near their communities?

Q73C.description: Fair revenue distribution from natural resource extraction
Q73C.question: Do local communities receive a fair share of revenue from nearby natural resource extraction?

Q73D.description: Cost-benefit analysis of resource extraction for communities
Q73D.question: Do the benefits of natural resource extraction, such as jobs and revenue, outweigh the environmental and social costs?

Q38A.description: Perceived corruption in the Office of the President
Q38A.question: How many people in the Office of the President, including the president and officials in their office, do you think are involved in corruption?

Q38B.question: How many members of Parliament do you think are involved in corruption?

Q38C.question: How many civil servants do you think are involved in corruption?

Q38D.description: Perceived corruption among local government councillors
Q38D.question: How many local government councillors do you think are involved in corruption?

Q38E.description: Perceived corruption in the police force
Q38E.question: How many police officers do you think are involved in corruption?

Q38F.description: Perceived corruption among judges and magistrates
Q38F.question: How many judges and magistrates do you think are involved in corruption?

Q38G.question: How many tax officials, such as those from the national revenue authority, do you think are involved in corruption?

Q38H.question: How many traditional leaders do you think are involved in corruption?

Q38I.question: How many religious leaders do you think are involved in corruption?

Q38J.question: How many business executives do you think are involved in corruption?

Q38K.question: How many people in non-governmental organizations do you think are involved in corruption?

Q39A.description: Perception of corruption trends over the past year
Q39A.question: In your opinion, over the past year, has the level of corruption in this country increased, decreased, or stayed the same?

Q39B.question: In this country, can ordinary people report incidents of corruption without fear, or do they risk retaliation or other negative consequences if they speak out?

values.1: Risk retaliation or other negative consequences

Q57A.description: Household affected by COVID-19 illness or positive test
Q57A.question: Have you or any member of your household become ill with or tested positive for COVID-19?

Q57B.description: Household lost income due to COVID-19
Q57B.question: Have you or any member of your household temporarily or permanently lost a job, business, or primary source of income due to COVID-19?

Q58A.question: Have you received a vaccination against COVID-19, either one or two doses?

Q58B.description: Likelihood of getting vaccinated for COVID-19
Q58B.question: If a vaccine for COVID-19 is available, how likely are you to try to get vaccinated?

Q58C.question: What is the main reason you would be unlikely to get a COVID-19 vaccine?

values.1: COVID doesn’t exist/COVID is not real
values.2: Not worried about COVID/COVID is not serious
values.3: I am at no risk or low risk for getting COVID
values.4: I already had COVID and believe I am immune
values.6: Don’t trust the vaccine/worried about fake vaccines
values.7: Don’t trust the government to ensure safety
values.13: Vaccine may cause other bad side effects
values.14: Vaccines are being used to control or track people
values.15: People are being experimented on with vaccines
values.19: Don’t trust the vaccine source/will wait for other vaccines
values.20: Effective treatments for COVID are or will be available
values.21: It is too difficult to get the vaccine
values.23: I don’t know how to get the vaccine
values.24: I will wait until others have been vaccinated
values.25: I will get the vaccine later

Q59.description: Trust in government to ensure COVID-19 vaccine safety
Q59.question: How much do you trust the government to ensure that any COVID-19 vaccine used in this country is safe?

Q60.question: How well or badly has the current government managed the response to the COVID-19 pandemic?

Q61A.description: Satisfaction with government COVID-19 relief efforts
Q61A.question: How satisfied or dissatisfied are you with the government’s response to COVID-19 in providing relief to vulnerable households?

Q61B.description: Satisfaction with government minimizing education disruptions
Q61B.question: How satisfied or dissatisfied are you with the government’s response to COVID-19 in ensuring that disruptions to children’s education are kept to a minimum?

Q61C.description: Satisfaction with government resourcing health facilities
Q61C.question: How satisfied or dissatisfied are you with the government’s response to COVID-19 in making sure that health facilities have adequate resources?

Q62.description: Level of corruption in COVID-19 response
Q62.question: Considering all funds and resources available for COVID-19 response, how much do you think was lost or stolen due to corruption?

Q63A.description: Support for censoring media during a pandemic
Q63A.question: During a public health emergency like COVID-19, is it justified for the government to censor media reporting?

Q63B.description: Support for armed forces enforcing health mandates
Q63B.question: During a public health emergency like COVID-19, is it justified for the government to use the police or security forces to enforce public health mandates, such as restrictions on gatherings or mask-wearing?

Q63C.description: Support for postponing elections during a pandemic
Q63C.question: During a public health emergency like COVID-19, is it justified for the government to postpone elections?

Q64A.description: Government preparedness for future health emergencies
Q64A.question: After experiencing the COVID-19 pandemic, how prepared do you think the government will be for future public health emergencies?

Q64B.description: Support for more investment in health emergency preparedness
Q64B.question: Should the government invest more in preparing for health emergencies like COVID-19, even if it means fewer resources for other health services?

Q65A.question: Since the start of the COVID-19 pandemic, have you or your household received any assistance from the government, such as food, cash payments, or relief from bill payments?

Q65B.description: Perceived fairness of COVID-19 relief distribution
Q65B.question: Do you think the distribution of government support during the COVID-19 pandemic, such as food packages or cash payments, has been fair or unfair?

region.description: Region, province, or state of respondent
region.question: Which region/province/state do you live in?

Q2.description: Primary language spoken in the home
Q2.question: What is the primary language you speak in your home?

values.9990: (National identity) only, or 'doesn't think of self in those terms'

Q84AOTHER.question: What is your ethnic community or cultural group?

Q84C.question: Do you identify more as a citizen of your country or as a member of your ethnic group?

values.1: Only as a member of my ethnic group
values.2: More as a member of my ethnic group than as a citizen of my country
values.3: Equally as a citizen of my country and as a member of my ethnic group
values.4: More as a citizen of my country than as a member of my ethnic group
values.5: Only as a citizen of my country

Q84D.question: Are you from the same ethnic community or cultural group as your mother?

values.2: Mother does not identify with an ethnic or cultural group

Q84E.question: Are you from the same ethnic community or cultural group as your father?

values.2: Father does not identify with an ethnic or cultural group

Q85B.description: Children belong more to mother’s or father’s side
Q85B.question: In your family, do the children belong more to the mother’s side, more to the father’s side, or to both sides equally?

Q93A.question: Do you have a job that pays a cash income? If yes, is it full-time or part-time? If no, are you presently looking for a job?

Q93B.question: What is your main occupation? If unemployed, retired, or disabled, what was your last main occupation?

values.6: Unskilled manual worker (e.g. cleaner, laborer, domestic help, unskilled manufacturing worker)
values.7: Artisan or skilled manual worker (e.g. trades like electrician, mechanic, machinist, or skilled manufacturing worker)
values.11: Mid-level professional (e.g. teacher, nurse, mid-level government officer)
values.12: Upper-level professional (e.g. banker/finance, doctor, lawyer, engineer, accountant, professor, senior-level government officer)

Q93BOTHER.question: What is your main occupation? If unemployed, retired, or disabled, what was your last main occupation?

Q93C.description: Who decides how money is used

values.3: I make the decisions jointly with my spouse
values.4: I make the decisions jointly with other family members
values.5: Other family members make the decisions without me
values.6: None of the above/Some other response

Q94.question: What is your highest level of education?

values.4: Intermediate school or some secondary school/high school
values.6: Post-secondary qualifications other than university, e.g. a diploma or degree from a polytechnic or college

Q95.question: What is your religion, if any?

values.1: Christian only (i.e., respondent says only 'Christian' without identifying a specific sub-group)
values.18: Muslim only (i.e., respondent says only 'Muslim' without identifying a specific sub-group)
values.19: Sunni only (i.e., respondent says only 'Sunni Muslim' without identifying a specific sub-group)

values.29: Atheist (Do not believe in a God)
values.820: United Church of Zambia or UCZ

Q96OTHER.question: If presidential elections were held tomorrow, which party’s candidate would you vote for?

Q8.question: When you get together with your friends or family, how often would you say you discuss political matters?

Q9A.description: Freedom to say what you think
Q9A.question: In this country, how free are you: to say what you think?

Q9B.description: Freedom to join any political organization
Q9B.question: In this country, how free are you: to join any political organization you want?

Q9C.description: Freedom to choose who to vote for
Q9C.question: In this country, how free are you: to choose who to vote for without feeling pressured?

Q10A.question: Have you attended a community meeting in the past year? If yes, how often?

values.1: No: Would if had the chance

Q10B.description: Join others to raise an issue
Q10B.question: Have you joined others to raise an issue in the past year? If yes, how often?

values.1: No: Would if had the chance

Q10C.description: Attend a demonstration or protest march
Q10C.question: Have you participated in a demonstration or protest march in the past year? If yes, how often?

values.1: No: Would if had the chance

Q11A.question: How likely is it that you could get together with others and make your local government councillor listen to your concerns?

Q11B.question: During the past year, how often have you contacted a local government councillor about an important problem or to give your views?

Q11C.question: During the past year, how often have you contacted a member of Parliament about an important problem or to give your views?

Q11D.question: During the past year, how often have you contacted a political party official about an important problem or to give your views?

Q11E.question: During the past year, how often have you contacted a traditional leader about an important problem or to give your views?

Q12A.description: Elections ensure MPs reflect views of voters
Q12A.question: Thinking about how elections work in practice in this country, how well do elections ensure that representatives to the National Assembly reflect the views of voters?

Q12B.description: Elections ensure voters remove unrepresentative leaders
Q12B.question: Thinking about how elections work in practice in this country, how well do elections enable voters to remove from office leaders who do not do what the people want?

Q13.description: Voting in the most recent national election
Q13.question: In the last national election, did you vote, or not, or were you too young to vote? Or can’t you remember whether you voted?

values.1: I was too young to vote
values.2: I can’t remember whether I voted

Q14A.description: Freeness and fairness of the last national election
Q14A.question: On the whole, how would you rate the freeness and fairness of the last national election?

values.2: Free and fair, but with major problems
values.3: Free and fair, but with minor problems

Q14B.description: How likely powerful find out your vote
Q14B.question: How likely do you think it is that powerful people can find out how you voted, even though there is supposed to be a secret ballot in this country?

Q14C.description: Last national election: fear political intimidation or violence
Q14C.question: During the last national election campaign, how much did you personally fear becoming a victim of political intimidation or violence?

Q15.description: Government bans organizations vs join any
Q15.question: Let’s talk for a moment about the kind of society you would like to have in this country. Which of the following statements is closest to your view? Statement 1: The government should be able to ban any organization that goes against its policies. Statement 2: We should be able to join any organization, whether or not the government approves of it.

Q16.description: Media free to publish vs government control
Q16.question: Which of the following statements is closest to your view?Statement 1: The media should have the right to publish any views and ideas without government control. Statement 2: The government should have the right to prevent the media from publishing things that it disapproves of.

Q17.description: Media checks government vs avoid negative reporting
Q17.question: Which of the following statements is closest to your view? Statement 1: The news media should constantly investigate and report on government mistakes and corruption. Statement 2: Too much reporting on negative events, like government mistakes and corruption, only harms the country.

Q18.description: Govt gets things done vs govt accountable to citizens
Q18.question: Which of the following statements is closest to your view? Statement 1: It is more important to have a government that can get things done, even if we have no influence over what it does. Statement 2: It is more important for citizens to be able to hold government accountable, even if that means it makes decisions more slowly.

Q19A.description: Government like a boss vs like an employee
Q19A.question: Which of the following statements is closest to your view? Statement 1: The government is like the people’s boss. People should respect the government and do what it directs. Statement 2: The government is like the people’s employee. It should respect the citizens and do what they request.

Q19B.description: Elected officials follow voter demands vs follow own ideas
Q19B.question: Which of the following statements is closest to your view? Choose Statement 1 or Statement 2. Statement 1: Statement 1: Our elected officials should listen to voters’ views and do what they demand. Statement 2: Our elected leaders should follow their own ideas in deciding what is best for the country.

Q20.description: Men only as leaders vs women leaders
Q20.question: Which of the following statements is closest to your view? Statement 1: Men make better political leaders than women, and should be elected rather than women. Statement 2: Women should have the same chance of being elected to political office as men.

Q21A.description: Men have more right to job
Q21A.question: Do you agree or disagree that when jobs are scarce, men should have more rights to a job than women?

Q21B.description: Women have equal right to land
Q21B.question: Do you agree or disagree that: Women should have the same rights as men to own and inherit land.

Q22A.question: There are many ways to govern a country. Would you disapprove or approve of the following alternative: Only one political party is allowed to stand for election and hold office?

Q22B.question: There are many ways to govern a country. Would you disapprove or approve of the following alternative: The army comes in to govern the country?

Q22C.question: There are many ways to govern a country. Would you disapprove or approve of the following alternative: Elections and the country's parliament are abolished so that the the country's president can decide everything?

Q23.question: Which of these three statements is closest to your own opinion? Statement 1: Democracy is preferable to any other kind of government. Statement 2: In some circumstances, a non-democratic government can be preferable. Statement 3: For someone like me, it doesn’t matter what kind of government we have.

Q24.description: Choose leaders through elections vs other methods
Q24.question: Which of the following statements is closest to your view? Statement 1: We should choose our leaders in this country through regular, open, and honest elections. Statement 2: Since elections sometimes produce bad results, we should adopt other methods for choosing this country’s leaders.

Q25.description: Political parties divisive vs many parties needed
Q25.question: Which of the following statements is closest to your view? Statement 1: Political parties create division and confusion; it is therefore unnecessary to have many political parties in Kenya. Statement 2: Many political parties are needed to make sure that Kenyans have real choices in who governs them.

Q26.description: Democracy needs political party turnover vs ok if one party always wins
Q26.question: Which of the following statements is closest to your view? Statement 1: In a democracy, it is better if power sometimes changes hands in elections from one political party to another. Statement 2: In a democracy, as long as a government is elected by the people in a free and fair election, it doesn’t matter if one party always wins and continuously governs the country.

Q27A.description: Parliament makes laws vs president does
Q27A.question: Which of the following statements is closest to your view? Statement 1: Members of Parliament represent the people; therefore they should make laws for this country, even if the president does not agree. Statement 2: Since the president represents all of us, he should pass laws without worrying about what Parliament thinks.

Q27B.description: President monitored by parliament vs free to act on own
Q27B.question: Which of the following statements is closest to your view? Statement 1: Parliament should ensure that the president explains to it on a regular basis how their government spends taxpayers’ money. Statement 2: The president should be able to devote full attention to developing the country rather than wasting time justifying their actions.

Q27C.description: Opposition parties examine government vs cooperate
Q27C.question: Which of the following statements is closest to your view? Statement 1: After losing an election, opposition parties should monitor and criticize the government in order to hold it accountable. Statement 2: Once an election is over, opposition parties and politicians should accept defeat and cooperate with government to help it develop the country.

Q28.description: President free to act vs obey the laws and courts
Q28.question:
Which of the following statements is closest to your view?
Statement 1: Since the country's president was elected to lead the country, they should not be bound by laws or court decisions that the country's president thinks are wrong.
Statement 2: The the country's president must always obey the laws and the courts, even if they think they are wrong.

Q29B.description: Armed forces never intervene vs when leaders abuse power
Q29B.question:
Which of the following statements is closest to your view?
Statement 1: The country’s armed forces should never intervene in the country’s political process.
Statement 2: It is legitimate for the armed forces to take control of government when elected leaders abuse power for their own ends.

Q30.question: Now let us speak about the political system in this country. In your opinion how much of a democracy is this country today?

values.3: A democracy, but with minor problems
values.8: Do not understand question/do not understand what ‘democracy’ is

Q31.question: Overall, how satisfied are you with the way democracy works in this country?

values.0: This country is not a democracy

Q32A.description: Level of democracy compared to five years ago
Q32A.question: Do you think that this country is more democratic, less democratic, or about the same than it was five years ago?

Q32B.description: Level of democracy in five years’ time
Q32B.question: Do you think that in five years’ time this country will be more democratic than it is now, less democratic, or about the same?

Q33A.description: How often party competition leads to conflict
Q33A.question: In your opinion, how often, in this country does competition between political parties lead to violent conflict?

Q33B.question: In your opinion, how often, in this country does the president ignore the courts and laws of this country?

Q33C.question: In your opinion, how often, in this country does the president ignore Parliament and just do what he wants?

Q33D.description: How often careful what you say
Q33D.question: In your opinion, how often, in this country do people have to be careful of what they say about politics?

Q33E.description: How often people treated unequally under the law
Q33E.question: In your opinion, how often, in this country: are people treated unequally under the law?

Q33F.question: In your opinion, how often, in this country: do officials who commit crimes go unpunished?

Q33G.question: In your opinion, how often, in this country: do ordinary people who break the law go unpunished?

Q33H.question: In your opinion, how free is the news media in this country to report and comment on the news without censorship or interference by the government?

Q33I.description: Treated unfairly by government based on economic status
Q33I.question: How often, if ever, are people treated unfairly by the government based on their economic status, that is, how rich or poor they are?

Q34A.question: How much of the time do you think the members of Parliament try their best to listen to what ordinary people have to say?

Q34B.question: How much of the time do you think the members of local government council try their best to listen to what ordinary people have to say?

Q77.description: Perceived influence of China's economic activities on the national economy
Q77.question: How much influence do you think China’s economic activities in this country have on our economy?

Q78A.description: Perceived economic and political influence of China on the country
Q78A.question: Do you think that the economic and political influence of China on this country is mostly positive or mostly negative?

Q78B.description: Perceived economic and political influence of the United States on the country
Q78B.question: Do you think that the economic and political influence of the United States on this country is mostly positive or mostly negative?

Q78C.description: Perceived economic and political influence of Japan on the country
Q78C.question: Do you think that the economic and political influence of Japan on this country is mostly positive or mostly negative?

Q78D.description: Awareness of Japan providing loans or development assistance to the country
Q78D.question: To your knowledge, does Japan give loans or development assistance to this country?

Q78E.description: Perception of Japan placing conditions on loans or assistance compared to other donors
Q78E.question: When the government of Japan gives loans or development assistance to this country, do they put more or fewer requirements compared to other donor countries?

values.2: About the same number of requirements

Q37A.question: How much do you trust the president?

Q37B.question: How much do you trust the national parliament?

Q37C.question: How much do you trust the national electoral commission?

Q37D.question: How much do you trust your elected local government council?

Q37E.question: How much do you trust the ruling political party?

Q37F.question: How much do you trust opposition political parties?

Q37G.question: How much do you trust the police?

Q37H.question: How much do you trust the army?

Q37I.description: Trust in the courts of law
Q37I.question: How much do you trust the courts of law?

Q37J.question: How much do you trust traditional leaders?

Q37K.question: How much do you trust religious leaders?

Q48A.description: Who is responsible for ensuring MPs do their jobs
Q48A.question: Who should be responsible for making sure that, once elected, members of Parliament do their jobs?

Q48B.description: Who is responsible for ensuring the president does his job
Q48B.question: Who should be responsible for making sure that, once elected, the president does his job?

Q84B.description: Ethnic group treated unfairly by government
Q84B.question: How often, if ever, are members of your ethnic group treated unfairly by the government?

Q85A.question: Please tell me whether you agree or disagree with the following statement: I feel strong ties with other citizens of my country.

Q86A.question: How much do you trust other citizens of your country?

Q86B.question: How much do you trust your relatives?

Q86C.question: How much do you trust your neighbours?

Q86D.question: How much do you trust other people you know?

Q86E.question: How much do you trust people from other religions?

Q86F.description: Trust people from other ethnic groups
Q86F.question: How much do you trust people from other ethnic groups?

Q87A.question: Would you like having people of a different religion as neighbours?

Q87B.question: Would you like having people from other ethnic groups as neighbours?

Q87C.question: Would you like having homosexuals as neighbours?

Q87D.question: Would you like having immigrants or foreign workers as your neighbours, dislike it, or not care?

Q87E.description: Neighbours: people who support a different political party
Q87E.question: Would you like having people who support a different political party as your neighbours, dislike it, or not care?

Q88A.description: Ok for family member to marry from different ethnic group
Q88A.question: Would you be okay with a family member marrying someone from a different ethnic group?

Q88B.description: Others see respondent as citizen like them
Q88B.question: Do you agree or disagree with the following statement: Other citizens think of me as a citizen just like them.

Q49A.description: Perceived equality of job opportunities between men and women
Q49A.question: Do women and men in this country have equal opportunities to get a job that pays a wage or salary?

Q49B.description: Perceived equality of land ownership and inheritance rights between men and women
Q49B.question: Do women and men in this country have equal opportunities to own and inherit land?

Q50A.description: Likelihood of increased community standing for a woman who runs for office
Q50A.question: If a woman in your community runs for elected office, how likely is it that she and her family will gain standing in the community?

Q50B.description: Likelihood of criticism or harassment for a woman who runs for office
Q50B.question: If a woman in your community runs for elected office, how likely is it that she will be criticized, called names, or harassed by others in the community?

Q50C.description: Likelihood of family problems for a woman who runs for office
Q50C.question: If a woman in your community runs for elected office, how likely is it that she will face problems with her family?

Q51A.description: Opinion on whether the government should do more or less for women's rights and equality
Q51A.question: Should the government and elected officials do more, less, or about the same as they are doing now to advance the rights and equality of women?

Q51B.description: Most important women’s rights issue that government should address
Q51B.question: Which women's rights and equality issues is the most important for the government and society to address?

values.0: None of these/There are no issues for government to address
values.2: Unequal opportunities or pay in the workplace
values.3: Too few women in influential positions in government
values.4: Unequal rights of property ownership and inheritance

Q52A.description: Justification of parents using physical discipline on children
Q52A.question: Do you think it is justified for parents to use physical force to discipline their children?

Q52B.description: Justification of a man using physical discipline on his wife
Q52B.question: Do you think it is justified for a man to use physical discipline on his wife if she has done something he doesn’t like or thinks is wrong?

Q53A.description: Perceived prevalence of violence against women
Q53A.question: How common do you think it is for men to use violence against women and girls in the home or in the community?

Q53B.description: Likelihood that police take reports of gender-based violence seriously
Q53B.question: If a woman in your community reports being a victim of gender-based violence, how likely is it that the police will take her case seriously?

Q53C.description: Likelihood of criticism or harassment for a woman reporting gender-based violence
Q53C.question: If a woman in your community reports being a victim of gender-based violence, how likely is it that she will be criticized, harassed, or shamed by others in the community?

Q54.description: Perception of domestic violence as a private matter vs. a criminal matter
Q54.question:
Which of the following statements is closest to your view? 
Statement 1: Domestic violence is a private matter that should be resolved within the family. 
Statement 2: Domestic violence is a criminal matter that requires the involvement of law enforcement agencies.

Q55A.description: Frequency of adults using physical force to discipline children in the community
Q55A.question: How frequently do adults use physical force to discipline children in your community or neighborhood?

Q55B.description: Frequency of child abuse, mistreatment, or neglect in the community
Q55B.question: How frequently are children abused, mistreated, or neglected in your community or neighborhood?

Q55C.description: Frequency of school-age children not attending school in the community
Q55C.question: How frequently do children who should be in school not attend school in your community or neighborhood?

Q56A.description: Availability of help for abused, mistreated, or neglected children
Q56A.question: In general, are people in this community able to get help for children who are abused, mistreated, or neglected?

Q56B.description: Availability of support for children with physical disabilities
Q56B.question: In your community, are children with physical disabilities generally able to get the support they need to succeed in life?

Q56C.description: Availability of support for children and adults with mental or emotional problems
Q56C.question: In your community, are children and adults with mental or emotional problems generally able to get the help they need to have a good life?
